trans-unit.source: User names within the system are known as authorization identifiers. The authorization identifier is a string that represents the name of the user, if one was provided in the connection request.

seg-source.mrk: User names within the system are known as authorization identifiers.
The authorization identifier is a string that represents the name of the user, if one was provided in the connection request.

target.mrk: User names within the system are known as authorization identifiers.
The authorization identifier is a string that represents the name of the user, if one was provided in the connection request.

trans-unit.source: For example, the built-in function CURRENT_USER returns the authorization identifier for the current user.

seg-source.mrk: For example, the built-in function CURRENT_USER returns the authorization identifier for the current user.

target.mrk: For example, the built-in function CURRENT_USER returns the authorization identifier for the current user.

trans-unit.source: Once the authorization identifier is passed to the system, it becomes an SQL92Identifier. SQL92Identifiers-the kind of identifiers that represent database objects such as tables and columns-are case-insensitive (they are converted to all caps) unless delimited with double quotes, are limited to 128 characters, and have other limitations.

seg-source.mrk: Once the authorization identifier is passed to the system, it becomes an SQL92Identifier.

SQL92Identifiers-the kind of identifiers that represent database objects such as tables and columns-are case-insensitive (they are converted to all caps) unless delimited with double quotes, are limited to 128 characters, and have other limitations.

target.mrk: Once the authorization identifier is passed to the system, it becomes an SQL92Identifier.

SQL92Identifiers-the kind of identifiers that represent database objects such as tables and columns-are case-insensitive (they are converted to all caps) unless delimited with double quotes, are limited to 128 characters, and have other limitations.

trans-unit.source: User names must be valid authorization identifiers even if user authentication is turned off, and even if all users are allowed access to all databases.

seg-source.mrk: User names must be valid authorization identifiers even if user authentication is turned off, and even if all users are allowed access to all databases.

target.mrk: User names must be valid authorization identifiers even if user authentication is turned off, and even if all users are allowed access to all databases.
